Headline: MILESTONES IN THE HISTORY OF LGBTI RIGHTS IN IRELAND
Offence Against the Persons Act
Text:
This law made “buggery” an offence. The punishment was penal servitude.
“Whosoever shall be convicted of the abominable crime of buggery, committed either with mankind or with any animal shall be liable… to be kept in penal servitude for life”.

Headline: Stonewall Riots take place in New York
Text:
Patrons of a gay bar in Lower Manhattan, called The Stonewall Inn, fight back against a police raid in the early morning hours of June 28th, 1969.
The protests are regarded as a vital step in the gay liberation movement.
Though faraway from Ireland, these events galvanised a global movement in the fight for the recognition of LGBTI equality rights.
Media Credit: Hilda Hedberg, Nico Petermann, Anna Lena Reisinger

Headline: Irish Gay Rights Movement is founded in Dublin
Text:
A campaign to decriminalise male homosexuality in Ireland begins (in the UK, it was decriminalised in 1967). The campaign centred on a legal challenge embarked on in 1977 by David Norris, a lecturer in English literature at Trinity College Dublin at the time.
The challenge claimed that anti-homosexuality laws violated an individual’s privacy according to the Constitution.
The challenge was defeated in the High Court, appealed to the Supreme Court, and defeated again.

Headline: The Hirschfeld Centre opens
Text:
Named after pioneering doctor and German gay activist, Dr. Magnus Hirshfield, it is the headquarter of the National Gay Federation.
It includes a library, a café, a cinema etc.

Headline: Murder of Declan Flynn
Text: On September 9th, Declan Flynn, a gay man, is killed in Fairview Park.

Headline: The GLEN (Gay and Lesbian Equality Now) campaign group is established.
Declan Flynn’s killers sentencing
Text: Declan Flynn’s killers are given suspended sentences.

Headline: Ireland’s first PRIDE parade
Text: Ireland’s first official Pride parade took place on June 25th.

Headline: Norris’s case is brought to the European Court of Human Rights
Text: Norris’s case is brought to the European Court of Human Rights and won.

Headline: Dr. Lydia Foy, a transgender woman, applies for a new birth certificate to the office of the Registrar General.
Text: The application is refused.

Headline: Same-sex sexual activity is decriminalised
Text:
On 24th June 1993, a legislation, called the “Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) 1993 Bill”, is officially passed that decriminalises homosexuality.

In the Irish Times the following day, Senator David Norris, whose case had been at the centre of the campaign, writes that “when, next week, this Bill is passed by Seanad Éireann and sent to the President for signature I will, for the first time in my life, feel that I am at last a full and equal citizen in my own country”.

Headline: Dr Lydia Foy launches High Court proceedings
Text:
Dr Lydia Foy launches High Court proceedings to have the Registrar issue her a new birth certificate.
She is represented by FLAC, or Free Legal Advice Centres, an independent voluntary organisation offering free and confidential legal information and advice to the public.

Headline: The High Court rules against Lydia Foy.
The European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) is enacted.
Text: This is a step toward the alignment of Irish domestic law with the European Convention in the domain of gender recognition rights.

Headline: Katherine Zappone and Ann Louise Gilligan High Court case
Text:
Katherine Zappone and Ann Louise Gilligan, who had married in British Columbia the year before, launch proceedings to the High Court to have their Canadian marriage recognised.
The development of this legal case is going to play a role in the movement for marriage equality.

Headline: Katherine Zappone and Ann Louise Gilligan High Court case
Text: The High Court does not grant Katherine Zappone and Ann Louise Gilligan what they hoped for.

Headline: After Dr. Lydia Foy launches new proceedings to the High Court
Text: After Dr. Lydia Foy launches new proceedings to the High Court, its judgment is that not recognising her new gender is a violation of her rights under the Article 8 of the ECHR

Headline: Katherine Zappone and Ann Louise Gilligan appeal their case to the Supreme Court.
The Gender Recognition Advisory Group is formed.
Civil partnerships are recognised
Text: The “Civil Partnership Act” is passed.

Headline: Katherine Zappone and Ann Louise Gilligan’s case is heard in the Supreme Court
Text: The Supreme court send the case back to the High Court.

Headline: A Gender Recognition Draft Bill is introduced.
Same-sex marriage referendum is passed
Text: The first time in the world that marriage equality is approved by popular vote.

Headline: Gender Recognition Act
Text: 22 years after Dr. Lydia Foy began her fight for new gender recognition, it became possible to apply to the Department of Social Protection for a “Gender Recognition Certificate” that recognised the applicant’s preferred gender.

Headline: Katherine Zappone
Text: 1st open and out lesbian to become a government minister

Headline: First openly gay head of government
Text: Leo Varadkar, who came out in2015, becomes Taoiseach.

Headline: National LGBTI+ Youth strategy published
Text: World's first LGBTI+ strategy published by the Irish government.

Headline: Irish government Apology
Text: Leo Varadkar issues an apology to Irish LGBTQI+ people who faced discrimination at the hands of the Irish State prior to decriminalisation of homosexuality in 1993

Headline: LGBTQI+ Strategy
Text: National LGBTQI+ Inclusion Strategy published 2019-2021

Headline: Unveiling
Text: Taoiseach Leo Varadkar unveils Ireland’s first AIDS memorial in the People’s Park situated in the Phoenix Park
Media:
Delighted to be at (and say a few words at) the unveiling of the National HIV/AIDS Monument in the Pheonix Park this afternoon. Grateful to the many people who worked to make this happen over the last number of years pic.twitter.com/a1wnlEbfU3

— Dr Panti Bliss-Cabrera (@PantiBliss) December 3, 2023

Headline: TV presenter
Text: Rebecca Tallon de Havilland becomes Ireland’s first transgender person to become a television presenter.
